tr.td: Predicting human resting-state functional connectivity from structural connectivity.
Connection density (number of connections per unit surface)

1) Low resolution, all connections: 0.66 2) Low resolution, removing absent/inconsistent connections: 0.82 3) High resolution, all connections: 0.36 4) High resolution, removing absent/inconsistent connections: 0.53
Measuring brain connectivity: diffusion tensor imaging validates resting state temporal correlations.
Weighted sum of connections; with penalizing more indirect pathways
The neonatal connectome during preterm brain development.
Between week 30 and week 42 of corrected gestational age
Network diffusion accurately models the relationship between structural and functional brain connectivity networks.
The structural–functional connectome and the default mode network of the human brain.
Number or random walks (probabilistic tractography (Prob)) and Number of fibers (global tracking (Global))
1) Prob. Full: 0.046 ± 0.018 (0.02–0.08) 2) Global. Full 0.017 ± 0.010 (0.006–0.02) 3) Prob. Partial: 0.024 ± 0.029. 4) Global. Partial 0.015 ± 0.017. (Individual participants)
Disrupted functional brain connectivity and its association to structural connectivity in amnestic mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer's disease.
Fiber numbers connecting each pair of brain regions
1) All connections: 0.37. 2) Excluding absent structural connections: 0.51.
Mapping the structural core of human cerebral cortex.
Deterministic tractography; connection density (number of connections per unit surface)
Altered functional and structural connectivity networks in psychogenic non-epileptic seizures.
Absolute functional connectivity strength; correlation coefficient
White matter maturation reshapes structural connectivity in the late developing human brain.
Product between connection density & apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC)
1) Young: low resolution: 0.30 2) Young: high resolution: 0.36 3) Old: low resolution: 0.43 4) Old: high resolution: 0.46
Abnormal rich club organization and functional brain dynamics in schizophrenia
1) Cortical: 0.25 ± 0.048 (mean ± SD) 2) Whole brain: 0.19 ± 0.049 (mean ± SD) 3) Cortical: 0.25 ± 0.062 (mean ± SD) 4) Whole brain: 0.18 ± 0.051 (mean ± SD)
A cross-modal, cross-species comparison of connectivity measures in the primate brain.
Probabilistic tractography: Streamline density (amount of tracts divided by distance and region size
Structural architecture supports functional organization in the human brain at a region wise and network level.
Probabilistic fiber tracking: Number of voxels between a pair of regions, weighted to surface area and corrected for mean tract length
Fisher's Z transformed Pearson’s correlation coefficient
1 and 2) p<0.001 for all subjects 3 and 4) Not reported
Structure–function relationships during segregated and integrated network states of human brain functional connectivity.
Number of streamlines divided by geometric mean of surface areas
Fisher’s Z transformed Pearson correlation coefficient
1) Integrated state: ∼0.27 2) Segregated state: ∼0.22 (Estimated from graph)
Whole-brain analytic measures of network communication reveal increased structure–function correlation in right temporal lobe epilepsy.
Resting-brain functional connectivity predicted by analytic measures of network communication.
1) Average all 3 datasets: r = 0.515. 2) Average all 3 datasets: r = 0.338.
Affected anatomical rich club and structural–functional coupling in young offspring of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder patients.
Number of streamlines rescaled to a Gaussian distribution
